characters: THE SUN, RISING OVER THE ZOO

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Daddy! I can’t have this milk. I’m lactose intolerant.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I know that --

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Mom always gave me Almond Milk.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: These waffles are not gluten free. Dad, you didn’t read the label.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: id morning?” INT. BENJAMIN’S CAR -- MORNING Benjamin is late, he’s got Subway sandwiches in the car, stuffing them into lunch-bags as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: So what are you telling me, Dylan?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t do the work.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You have to focus. If you focused on your homework like you focused on your artwork, you’d have it all. As it is —-

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Hey Dad --

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (to Dylan) -~ you‘re going to get an F! Dylan drops a truth bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad. Nobody’s going to give an “F” to a guy whose Mom died six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FRONT OF SCHOOL
dialogues.text: Benjamin unloads. A wheel comes off Dylan's pack.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Shi...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Owe me a dollar! Benjamin is barely able to balance the swirling duties.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I didn’t complete the word -~

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I got it, Dad. I got it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCHOOL MOTHERS
dialogues.text: Watching nearby. They share a look at each other, evaluat Benjamin’s lack of parenting ease. One holds a Hello Kitt bag. Another wears the perfect sweats and Jackie O shades They have mothering down to a designer—accessorized scien One of them is sentimental. She holds a Pyrex dish as she watches Benjamin get his kids through the school’s front loor.

dialogues.speaker: SENTIMENTAL MOTHER
dialogues.text: Mr. Mee! I thought maybe... She pushes the Pyrex towards him. SENTIMENTAL MOTHER (CONT’D) ++. Lasagna. Benjamin takes it and thanks her silently. He looks at th Pyrex dish. She sees he still wears his wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. I’11 get this dish back to you --

dialogues.speaker: SENTIMENTAL MOTHER
dialogues.text: ~- in time. In time. He nods. It‘s the sympathy conversations that he finds hardest. Rosie waves to him, knowing somehow that wave wa exactly what he needed, at that exact moment. He waves ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and his brother, DUNCAN, 30's, walk the business courtyard near Duncan's office. It's lunchtime busy. Dunc and Benjamin have a unique way of speaking. Somehow, long ago, they settled on a rhythm of offering noble pronouncements to each other.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Benjamin. I_have arrive

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Tell me, Dunc.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I think you should call that girl we met at Jamba Juice. Benjamin looks slightly horrified.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Benjie, she was a stunner.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: She wasn’t beautiful like my Katherine. Duncan has stopped. Their favorite donut place is closed.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: “Closed temporarily for renovations.” Bernie's hungover again.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: A “stunner?” Really? Benjamin scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: All right, let’s think, there’s... well, how about Neal’s? Duncan indicates a place nearby, on the corner. It’s Neal a coffee shop with cool wooden booths. Benjamin stiffens noticeably, won’t even look at the place.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Dunean.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Look, the world is going to get very small if you don’t go to any places where you guys uséd to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met her there.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, I’m sorry. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I gotta get back to work anyway. We’ll go out later this week.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Okay then. Benjamin starts to go, but Duncan grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Benjie. Let a little sunlight in. Human interaction is a good thing. It‘ll help you start again. You need _to start again. He holds his fist out for a bump.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on. It’s the new “high-five.” Benjamin reluctantly bumps.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I miss the high-five.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You “miss” everything. Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (courtly) I will attempt to “start over.”

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I love you, my brother. They hug. And they do love each other. A lot.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Thanks man. Benjamin strides away.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Benjie! Benjamin turns. Duncan spreads his arms, it’s a beautiful day. He demonstrates the art of “basking.” DUNCAN (CONT‘D) “Sunlight!” “Human interaction!“  Benjamin bows. I got it. DUNCAN (CONT‘D) "Joy!" Benjamin pauses to admire his brother -- who roots for “J like it’s a football team. He smiles and turns. INT. SAN DIEGO UNION ELEVATOR —- DAY Benjamin stands in the workplace elevator. He looks over a WOMAN, who nods with sympathy. He nods back. Then at ANOTHER WOMAN. She nods, with understanding sympathy. He returns a small smile. Then he looks at a MAN, who looks him with obliging sympathy. It’s getting to be too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin meets his editor, DELBERT McGINTY, 50’s. McGinty old-school, patches on the elbows of his coat. Last of a dying breed.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Alright, McGinty, so get this. I go to the Volcano eruption site. I_tak ids. And I write about... the end of the world, from the point of view of the generation that will save it. And we do a whole thing about life being elemental, and all the software and laptops and apps in the world can’t change it, and the piece is called, get this... i-Pocalypse.

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: Wow. Just... wow.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: i see it as a series. Like the Killer Bees.

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: That is bold stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You‘re not going to say “yes” are you?

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: (immediate, truthful) No.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Right. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I think we should give you an online column. That way you’re protected. If the paper goes down, or gets sold, you're still safe. You'll be virtual, you'll be “viral”...

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Don’t keep me around out of...

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: I’m not -~

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: s+. out of sympathy. I hate sympathy. I’m sick of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: {sympathetic} I know.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You know what ——

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: Bad things happen. You just keep going.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: -- I quit.

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: No. I’m not going to sit around here and spin my wheels and live in a state of... of sponsored pity.

dialogues.speaker: MCGINTY
dialogues.text: Please, just let me lay you off so you get the benefits.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: That is more sympathy. No! I resign. And I love you, and your patched elbows, and I salute you, and all our good times together, and I quit. His cell-phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin moves importantly up the stairs.  INT. PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE -~ DAY Benjamin sits in the chair next to his son. Together they stare straight ahead. A breeze blows the hand-crank windo back and forth. Squeak, squeak, squeak.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Classy. Real classy.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: They left the cash box right out on the counter. Kinda their fault if you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Three suspensions in one semester. That’s got to be some kind of record. Benjamin stares at the squeaky window.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Maybe I’il get a prize.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Was that a joke? Could you possibly be making a “joke” right now? Because if you think -- (re: the window) JESUS, that’s annoying. Benjamin gets up and walks over to the window. Dylan watc him work at it. The PRINCIPAL walks in. Sees lan sitting alone. Dylan gestures to the window. Benjamin has already got the window unhinged and is working on it. He looks up They're staring at him. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) The window frame was loose. Tightening it for you. Just... one second... He uses his car-key screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: I‘m fine with my squeaky window, Mr. Mee. Benjamin abandons the window.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Besides today’s theft, there is a darkness here that we should deal with. Mr. Devereaux, Dylan’s art teacher, wanted you to see his wall mural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along a pleasant row of large-sized student mur Sunflowers. A portrait of Bob Marley. A treatment of the word “Love,” and then... a very dark portrait of humanity that only Francis Bacon could love.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Guess which one is your son. Benjamin stares at this horrible portrait.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are a three strikes school, Mr. Mee. Today was his third strike. I'm sorry we have to expel Dylan. But_as one parent to another, I would examine his inner life. EXT. PARKING LOT —- AFTERNOON They walk in silence. Benjamin barely keeps a lid on.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: It’s like he was expelling me for my artwork.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: No. He wasn’t expelling you because of your artwork. I can almost live with the artwork. I mean, if Charles Manson needed a personal muralist, you would definitely have the job... if the devil himself came back and started a singing career, walk away, this. wou. hi: cover, but no... no, he wasn’t expelling you for your artwork. He was expelling you because you stole. You stole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin takes the sad dish of Lasagna and opens the refrigerator. The dish joins stacks of dishes of Lasagna other sympathy food gifts. Nearby, Rosie is making peanut butter-and-jelly sandwiches for tomorrow. She has taken o “wifely” duties -- even at 6.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: One day you’re going to have to eat some of that Lasagna, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Honey...  10.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Or throw it away. Benjamin sits down and sighs. He watches her carefully putting the sandwiches in Ziploc bags.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: +++ what happened to your playdate? Why didn’t you want to go to Sadie‘s?

dialogues.speaker: ROSTE
dialogues.text: No reason. Just lots to do here.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Hey Rosie. Am I doing anything right?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: (thinks) You‘re handsomer than the other dads. A lotta them don’t have hair. So that’s good.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: What if I go bald?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: We'll call those numbers on the t.v. ads, where the men grow bald- guy hair.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Good. I’m gonna take baldness off my list of stuff to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Good! She checks an imaginary box. He smiles. she labels the lunches in her 6 year-old scrawl. INT. DYLAN’S ROOM -- NIGHT Benjamin looks in. Asleep, Dylan looks much younger and m serene. Benjamin moves to his kid, pushes aside the mod hair, and kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Rosie’s forehead. Rises up. Stuffed animals are piled around her, she looks like one of them.  11. INT. BATHROOM -— NIGHT Benjamin washes his face before bed. He sees the other wa basin in the bathroom. It’s Katherine’s basin. Her skin creams. Her brushes, Her medicine. All still there. A note in her handwriting, the hours and times to take medication. He holds onto the sink basin and can barely stand up straight.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Daddy, I can’t sleep... The neighbors again. He turns to face her, smiling and calm.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Aw honey... He goes to the window. The Neighbors. Their music is loud Their laughter is loud.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Their “happy” is too loud. He turns to her. An idea has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long-faced REAL-ESTATE MAN attempts small talk.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: We have a full day of house hunting Planned, and I think you’ll be very excited at what’s available -~

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: «+. we need “new”. New schools, new opportunities. New.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: I think you'll find that in our current economic environment, the buyer is King.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: King Daddy! Rosie is still in her pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: (humorless) Where to first, “King Daddy?”  12.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I’d like a big yard, something substantial, some rolling hills, just whatever comes to mind when I say “new.”

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Rolling hills might be hard in the eity.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: They don’t even have to roll. They can be stationary hills. Right, Rosie? Rosie has a seat-belt on her stuffed dinosaur. She’s eati animal crackers, leafing through the real estate binder.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I wish Dylan had come with us! This is fun! The Real-Estate Man remains humorless.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Our adventure begins.

dialogues.speaker: ON A HOUSE
dialogues.text: Not quite right.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANOTHER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Very not right.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ON YET ANOTHER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Perfect, white-picket fence. (We are getting more rural.)

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmmm. No.

dialogues.speaker: ON STILL ANOTHER HOUSE
dialogues.text: With overgrown lawn.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN/ROSIE
dialogues.text: No. Not quite. The Real-Estate Man is unamused. Benjamin and Rosie’s repartee is not his style.  13.

dialogues.speaker: REAL
dialogues.text: We are now running out of options.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Dad. Benjamin turns to see that Rosie has found a flyer from d in the back-seat binder. She presents it grandly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are definitely out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin clutches the listing with growing excitement.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: ++. what would we do with 18 acres?

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: I have to be honest. The Rosemoor property has some challenges.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: What. doesn’t?

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: True, but this situation is, I’m going to offer this word -- “unique”... Benjamin sees the road leading to the property.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Yes. And —

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Rosie, look. Their faces press against the car window. Music. A small tingle, a single instrument playing a melody —- our Theme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass through a tree-lined entrance. It’s enticing... a artfully run-down American Colonial house... rolling hill a property gloriously in need of love... maybe even them. here is a masterpiece. As music continues.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, holding Rosie (and her dinosaur and a small pur on his shoulders, looks at the property.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Mee, we need to talk... Benjamin ignores the Real-Estate Man, moving closer to th house. Above him, Rosie reaches for her purse and withdra a small kiddie camera. Music grows, their hearts pound. H feels destiny.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to take a picture, Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (very simply) Because we’re going to live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Real-Estate Man fiddles with keys.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: This is exactly what we've been looking for.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Well, let’‘s not get ahead of ourselves... The door opens, and Benjamin and Rosie bound past him. Th house is musty, but crackles with promise. INT. BEDROOM --— LATER DAY Benjamin and Rosie are in the master bedroom. Rosie peers out the window at the landscape, her head just clearing t sill. The Real-Estate Man joins them.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: It’s perfect. Why didn’t you tell us about it earlier?

dialogues.speaker: REAL
dialogues.text: It’s a bit complicated.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Complicated is okay. Complicated can be great. We love complicated, don‘t we, Rosie? Rosie nods, as if she had any idea what that meant.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what‘s so complicated about this place?

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: You see, it’s... it’s um... The Real-Estate Man hems, not quite sure how to put it.

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --. frankly, it’s... We hear a loud, bone-rattling crushing ROAR. So loud, so intense, it sounds like it’s in the same room with them. REAL-ESTATE MAN (CONT’D) w+. it’s a zoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Real-Estate Man, Benjamin and Rosie stand in front of SOLOMON. Solomon happens to be a large African lion with majestic mane, standing at attention, studying these strangers suspiciously. Benjamin and Rosie stare at the awesome animal. Separated only by a small moat, alone in zoo, the relationship between man and animal gets a littl more... personal. Solomon ROARS again. And this one, close-up, rips our hea off. They collect themselves. Mournfully:

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: It was a fully functioning zoo until two years ago and then it was shut down. The estate is maintaining it for now —-

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: But can’t I... I mean, if we bought this place, we could just relocate the animals, right?

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN
dialogues.text: Actually, the estate is selling it with the stipulation that whoever buys this place has to continue caring for the animals. And +--+. the remaining staff. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: REAL-ESTATE MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If it doesn't sell soon, the animals... will probably be... He looks at Rosie, and Benjamin, as in ~- “put down.” Benjamin shares a reality-~look with Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Well, thanks. I don't know anything about zoos and animals. It’s a great property, but no one is going to buy it under those conditions. I mean it’s a -~

dialogues.speaker: REAL-
dialogues.text: -- exactly, and that’s why it’s been on the market so long. And why I didn’t show it to you. Benjamin looks around, disappointed. His eyes fall downwa He can no longer look at Solomon.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Well, it’s just... it’s too bad. Alright. We'll keep looking. Come on, Rosie, let's... He doesn't see Rosie. For a moment, panic.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rosiel!! No sign of her.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perfect. I keep her home from school one day and she gets eaten. The Real-Estate Man takes a few steps, and spots her in a nearby clearing. He points.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: She's surrounded by a small crowd of peacocks and peahens spreading their fans in the air. She’s in the middie, delighted, feeding them her animal crackers. Relaxed, hap carefree, a kid. Music returns. It’s Rosie’s Theme.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boy, it’s a shame that we can’t just...

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Shot pushes in. Pure joy has returned to his life, in som small way. He watches his daughter’s spontaneous romp wit these scrappy peacocks. Her happiness is breathtaking. He sits down on a nearby stump, quietly overwhelmed.  17. There is no one to share this feeling with. The Real-Esta Man is already trudging up the hill. Benjamin looks aroun for someone, for Katherine, for anybody. He is at the crossroads of a powerful life decision. He turns and find an understanding pair of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SOLOMON
dialogues.text: The Lion stares at him with ancient wisdom. His eyes say. yes. Yes is the answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin and Duncan hang at their donut place. He address his brother carefully, like a jumper on a very tall ledge

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I said... “human” interaction.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: It’s destiny, Dunc. The owner died, the place fell into disrepair, and the estate’s had trouble unloading it. I'm telling you, we can get a deal on it, too.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: A “deal?”

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You've been through a difficult stretch. This is what people do when they have a you-know-what happen in their life. They lose their way a little bit, you know, they go “hey ~~ I think I'11 quit my Job and try something new with my life.” And then they wake up later and say, “Wow. I'm reall glad my brother didn‘t let me blow dad’s inheritance to ... " Duncan leans forward, tired of playing along. DUNCAN (CONT’D) Or fete) i i a ‘o arest dk Est 7

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: But that person you’re talking about, they didn’t see this place. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the way, there’s even a semi- functioning restaurant on the property. It’s called The Jaguar. Duncan adjusts his brother’s coat. He is tender again.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: It's not your life, Benjie. You got kids.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: According to the seller's estate, you don’t need any specialized knowledge to run a small zoo. Just a lot of heart.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: And CASH. All your cash.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to run my own business. Katherine and I talked about it.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Wait a second. Wait.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: The zoo makes 75 percent of its revenue in the summer. All we have to do is get Rosemoor open again by Memorial Day and -—-

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You're losing it. I gave you a pass when you freaked out about going to Neal‘s.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Hey. This isn’t about Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Please, I beg you. Do what others do. Go to Vegas, lose a lot of money. Travel through the stages but stop before... of grief -- but. sto . zebras get involved.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: No zebras. Just a Lion, a Jaguar and 47 other animals, 7 endangered species. All of them, saved, when we make this deal. Duncan knows the die has been cast. He's horrified and concerned and distraught.  19.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Holy Jesus. That’s all I have to say. Holy, and Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I haven't doubted this decision for one second. Isn’t that crazy?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: The kids will be so psyched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosie is serving dinner to the two men in her life.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: You're freaking kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Don’t say “freakin” to me. Show some respect.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: It's called the Rosemoor Animal Park and it’s 18 acres and wait until you see the animals.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: My friends are here, our life is here!

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I’m surprised at you. What did we talk about, a new start, a new place...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: That’s what you want. That’s not what I want. But you‘re not asking me, are you? Rosie sets down a dish. Excited and enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: We bought the zoo?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: No -- we didn’t. He did.  20. Dylan pushes back his chair and exits. Benjamin sighs, lo at Rosie, her face lit up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: We bought a zoo!!!! Benjamin and Rosie laugh with joy. Leon barks, cheerful. INT. MEE‘S BEDROOM -- DAY Benjamin packs. He's powered by destiny, can’t move fast enough. He dumps a handful of clothes into a box marked f Goodwill. Rosie walks over, looks in the box and fishes out... a tattered college sweatshirt that says: USD. She holds it up to him ~-- really?

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Mommy used to wear this sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, it started out as mine, but it’s all zipped up now so -- (off her look) I know, it’s hard to throw stuff out sometimes. They regard the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know. Keep it, right? Benjamin looks at Rosie. She understands what this means.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: It’s time. Let that sweatshirt start over. He throws the sweatshirt into the Goodwill box. And then holds up a severely tattered stuffed monkey.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I couldn't find the little Converse shoes that he used to wear...

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Never. That we’re keeping.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: (immediately) Okay. Benjamin laughs and throws the monkey on the keep pile.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin is at the wheel of the moving van. Dylan draws i the backseat, lost in his headphones, as Rosie’ bounces happily. Benjamin intentionally drives past... Neal’s Cof Shop. He catches a view of the corner booth, disappearing into his past. He says goodbye with a simple gesture that only Rosie sees.

dialogues.speaker: HIS MEMORY
dialogues.text: Brief, just a glimpse. A woman in the booth, turned away.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're here! EXT. ROSEMOOR ENTRANCE —- RAINY LATER AFTERNOON They turn down the driveway, and gain their first family of the Rosemoor property. In this gray rainy afternoon light, it looks much less appealing. More scary and decre than beautiful. leon whimpers, and yelps. Dylan lets out long judgmental whistle. Benjamin doesn’t notice. He only sees the beauty. He will not be deterred. In fact, he’s enthralled. He drives a victory lap around the property.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Look. The Jaguar Restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JAGUAR RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: A place on the outskirts of the property. A girl, 15, (LI arranges the letters on a small “do-it-yourself” neon sig the window. It reads: WELCOME BRAVE NEW OWNERS. BENJAMIN (CONT‘D) How great is that!? He honks. Dylan notices the girl, who waves to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, Rosie and Dylan help FOUR MOVERS unload the Mee Van. Wolves are howling in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They open the door to the back kitchen entrance. This sid of the house needs a lot of work. They are hit with an overwhelming smell.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Right, this is the storage side of the house...  22. He consults a small “owner’s manual” for the home.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --- this is where they stored the snake food... dead rats... stillborn chicks, that sort of thing. Been reading up on everything -- whew...

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I miss our home. Benjamin nods gamely. Shoves open the main residence door

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Alright! We’re in!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. 200
dialogues.text: The STAFF is lined up at the entrance. They look at Benja like an exotic species of animal. We meet the RAGGED CREW Zookeepers. ELLIS, 65, is a tall man with a beanie and white beard. ROBIN, 30, a worker. From Orange County. And their spokesman is... KELLY, 28, Head Zookeeper. Pretty, with to-the-bone communication skills. She has a strong grip. Humans are n her thing. She’s an animal person.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I‘m Kelly Foster, Head Zookeeper, and over here is Robin, and Ellis. Robin is our craftsman. Ellis is our Visionary. He built the enclosures that set the standard for modern zoos all across America.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: (attempting modesty) And the world.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: And the world. Yes, and he and Robin do... well, basically everything. And this is my cousin Lily. She’s fifteen. Lily has already met eyes with Dylan, who looks away quic (She‘s a rural beauty, he’s a city curiosity.)  23.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She can’t legally work here so we pay her cash under the table out of ™My salary. She lives on the property, works out of the Jaguar. And that‘s... basically it. it’s just us, Mr. Mee.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Great to meet you guys. I’m Benjamin. This is Rosie, and this is Dylan, my eldest. And, this is our zoo now, I guess. They look at him oddly. Not a particularly rousing speech He presses forward, searching for connection with them. BENJAMIN (CONT‘D) So I declare us all... Modern Day Adventurers... and Sponsors of Animal Greatness! It’s not quite killing ‘em. He claps his hands together. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) Okay! Onward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, Rosie and Dylan walk through the zoo with the STAFF. Rosie looks at everything with wonder. Dylan follows, hands dug deep in pockets. Lily is an extrovert, she sidles up to Dylan, sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Uh, fourteen, I guess. He feels comfortable and uncomfortable, at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Where are the otters? I‘d love to see the otters and the snakes and the monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (to Benjamin) Listen, when you get a chance. There are a few things we wanted to jo over with you about our upcoming inspection. Benjamin flips through the paperwork, a quick study.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: That would be the -- the USDA inspector. Walt Ferris.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: I’/1i kill him! 1'11 --

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Ellis. Stop. Ellis stops. She has strange control over this white-hair firecracker of a man. The peacocks cross their path, several raising their fans displaying feathers.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t get old, does it?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: What, the peacocks? Dumbest animals in the place. And we're overrun with ‘em. In the old days we used to feed the extra ones to the bears.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: (unconvincing) Though nowadays that sort of thing is frowned upon. Rosie looks distraught.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Speaking of which, if I’m you, I‘m keeping your dog —-

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Leon.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Leon needs to stay away from the snake habitat. He’s got “lunch” written all over him.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Got it. He makes this note on his notepad. (The same red notepad used as a reporter.) Lily lingers to walk next to Dylan, still sizing him up. He tries to act casual, awkwardly.  25. EXT. ANOTHER PATH/BEAR ENCLOSURE —- DAY They arrive at the Bear Enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: And that’s Buster, a 650 pound North American Grizzly. He was 770 but he’s been stressed. He’s moody. We had him on Paxil, but we can’t afford it anymore so he’s a little depressed occasionally.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Hey Buster. Missing the meds? Buster swipes at the air, viciously.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m on the natch too. The Animal Keepers share some looks. Lily leans over to Dylan, confiding privately:

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Talking to the animals has to be done in a super specific way. He doesn’t have it yet. He’ll learn. Dylan nods. She's so interested in Dylan. LILY (CONT’D) Where did you get your shoes and how much did they cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pass the Otters and the Monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Walter Ferris is a creep. Benjamin shuffles through paperwork, makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: “Ferris -- Creep.”

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You can just talk to me, you don’t need to make notes. Ferris shut us down once before. We'd gotten a little behind, as you know, with this small staff... They pass an enclosure with a homely creature who looks l a large dark brown pig with an elephant snout. Rosie poin  26.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s a tapir -- Ronnie. Ronnie looks over at them. He locks eyes with Benjamin. It’s a baleful, sincere look.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Poor guy. We've brought in female tapirs but they won't have anything to do with him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Think he might be ugly for a tapir, but it's kinda hard to tell. Ronnie, eyes still on Benjamin, reaches his snout through fence. Benjamin reaches toward him, curious. Ronnie looks at him, thoughtfully... and methodically wipes tapir snot over Benjamin's hand.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Ronnie... a pleasure. Rosie laughs. Kelly offers a towel from her back pocket. lan backs away, horrified at this new life. Behind him, Lily is still riveted on this new kid from the city.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Can we see the tigers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand across the moat from three tigers -- two young females and an older male, grizzled around the whiskers. There is a weathered elegance about the older male. He is SPAR, and he walks gingerly across the exhibit, a bit cre but filled with a grand sense of supremacy. Everyone, eve the keepers, view these tigers with a sense of awe. Even Dylan draws closer with interest.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: I thought they would roar. Like Solomon the Lion. Kelly is slightly annoyed by this constant misconception.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Tigers and Lions -- very different. Tigers don’t really growl or roar, they “chuff.” Kelly skillfully demonstrates, making the sound, which so like blowing a raspberry, using her top lip.  27.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You chuff at them, they chuff back. She chuffs to the tigers. The tigers gently chuff back at Kelly. Kelly turns to Rosie.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do it. Rosie tries. Nothing. Then tries again. Spar looks over a her, and chuffs back. Rosie’s eyes go wide. KELLY (CONT’D) That... is Spar, the oldest. He's 17. He’s a Siberian Tiger. You know, tigers have special sensors along the front of their two-inch canines. They can detect the pulse in your aorta. When they attack, they bite you, take your pulse with their teeth, reposition those suckers, and boom, there goes your carotid.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Wow! Boom. We hear the sound of a gunshot.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: What was that --

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: One of our Lionesses. Lung cancer. The vet said -- it’s time. Benjamin looks around. No Ellis.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Ellis did that?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (neds) Life around here is pretty elemental.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Can we go back to the house, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, Rosie and Dylan walk up the hill. Kelly joins.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: -- there are a few decisions you’11 have to make right away, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin. Ben was my dad.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Spar, who you just met, the tiger, is going to need some extra care. We need to have him seen by the large animal vet from San Diego, and he’s a fortune to get here -- Benjamin feels his budding altruism.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Fine. Set it up.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: -- it’s expensive.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: He’s sick, he needs a doctor, so --

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: He’s also very old, Ben.... jamin. Truth is, we don't know how much longer.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Get the doctor. I/’11 pay. She‘s impressed. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) What's next for today?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (brightening) Okay, we've got massive problems with plumbing, antiquated wiring, inadequate refrigeration for storing the carcasses for the big cats -- you don’t want to be there on a hot day, you’1l pass out from the smells -~

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Got it. Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Rickety posts. Beak rot on the tortoises. A weak enclosure between the Jaguars and the Tigers. They don’t get along. And --

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Okay, enough. We'll start with the cages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The... what? She glares at him, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Posts in the cages.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Cages? They’re not cages. They're enclosures. No one has called them a cage in about a century.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Alright then --

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: My brief marriage? That was a cage.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Not mine. 29. And now Kelly stops walking. She lets the others continue on. She turns to him, dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: RELLY
dialogues.text: I have a question. Benjamin looks at her, ready for anything. KELLY (CONT’D) You're some random guy, no one in the zoo community has ever heard of you. You know nothing about animals, you’ve moved into a dump. What regular person just 4p and buys this place? Especially some one with kids. Why? He doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have no idea what we’ve been dealing with here. We used to have three times this staff. They quit. I‘m 28, I never go out, I’m here all the time. I’m here every day. I had to move back with my mother. I couldn't pay my mortgage. No one gets paid, Ben... jamin. We're so understaffed. We need volunteers. He is stunned by her raw devotion to these animals.  30.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need someone to really take charge of this place. Or we, and all these animals, are gone.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: So your question is --

dialogues.speaker: RELY
dialogues.text: (simply) Why’d you buy this place?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Why not? He smiles and moves on. She stands still. EXT. BENJAMIN’S OFFICE -- NIGHT A gentle wind whips at the trees by the window. At his se at Katherine’s old family table, Benjamin looks at the bi spread out before him. The weight of it all hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin stands on the porch. He hears what few of us eve hear. The sounds of a zoo, alive, at night. It’s a gorgeo cacophony, instruments in a symphony. He’s falling in lov with his new life. And in the distance, the gentle sound laughter. INT. DYLAN’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT Dylan is still awake, listening to the unfamiliar noises Carefully, he reaches under the bed and fishes around unt he finds what he’s looking for. A picture frame. It’s a hoto of Dylan, Rosie and their mother, Katherine. (Her fa is obscured in the darkness.) He cradles it with everythi he’s got, and waits for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin squishes down the hill, through some mud, headin towards the laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant at night is the hub of the place. It’s the staff's hang-out, their clubhouse.  31. Lily works on the letters for tomorrow's sign in the wind The restaurant is filled with artifacts and curios, inclu a dartboard with a vain-looking man’s face on it. (It’s Walter Ferris, the USDA Inspector. His face is also on an ancient COFFIN in the corner.) Ellis, holding a whisky an nursing a toothache, launches darts at the board. He spea to a few workers, as he pulls darts out of Ferris’ face.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS
dialogues.text: Walter Ferris. I’11 kill him. I will. I‘ll cut off his head with a sword -- I’11 kill him without a thought. And, he borrowed $500 from me in the 80's, and claims he doesn’t remember. Crook! Kelly is playing chess with Rob at the bar counter. She's heard it all before. A few odd locals are here too. An ol school big screen projection TV plays satellite soccer. A stereo plays an old garage rock song from the 60’s. Ellis wails along with it, as if it were a sea-shanty. The door opens. Benjamin stands there, witnessing the par he hasn’t been invited to. All stop and stare at him. He decides to join them, uninvited, walking a few steps into place. It’s an awkward moment. Until Ellis pulls out an empty chair with his foot and sh it Benjamin’s way.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {a bit drunk) It's the most dangerous animal in the forest! The Adult Boomer Male! Benjamin smiles, tips an imaginary hat, and sits down. Ke points at her beer -- want one? Benjamin nods. He sings along to the old song, along with Ellis. Camaraderie continues, wordlessly, as they return to thei previous behavior. Kelly brings over the beer.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Here you go, Boss. She sets it at his table.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Welcome to your zoo, Benjamin Mee. She moves on with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin, wearing new tool-belt and boots, takes a look around the zoo. He takes a deep breath. A lot of work.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin walks purposefully into the Porcupine enclosure. repiaces a crumbling wooden post. Two PORCUPINES watch calmly. He speaks to them, in a voice still slightly too folksy and self-aware.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Hey Guys. You are going to love your new enclosure. Look at the quality of this new post -~ Benjamin calls over to Robin, carrying feed. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) They‘re so docile!

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Not at night. Benjamin BANGS down a new wooden post.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: So you get wild at night, huh? In a flash, one of the Porcupines wheels around and in reverse, begins charging him with razor-sharp quills bare Benjamin HOPS the enclosure, pronto. He falls over the fence, into a thicket of nettles. Nettles. Worse than quills. Benjamin begins picking them out, painfully.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (laughing) You don’t talk to them correctly, Boss. Be real with them. They can tell the difference. Benjamin speaks to the Porcupine who shot him. He’s pisse

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You —- I’m never talking to you again... you little glorifiel rodent

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (without looking over) Now you’re talking to him... Benjamin is getting it, and loving the journey. INT. BACKYARD —- DAY -- SAME TIME Dylan is drawing on his sketch-pad in the backyard, and L shows up with a basket of sandwiches.  33.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing? You want a sandwich?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: (shy) No, that’s okay. She invites herself to sit next to him. He pretends to be casual. She looks at his drawing, and at him.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You got a nosebleed.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I know. He continues drawing, and she uncomfortably studies his w

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How’d you get the nosebleed? He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: I slipped on the roof and banged it.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s a weird house. She stares at his drawing. LILY (CONT‘’D) I like your drawing.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s a little dark. Where's the sun?

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: There’s no sun in the Underworld. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m off at 4.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Cool. She gets up to return to work.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Alright so I might come back later. Dylan remains focused on his work.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: Okay. She exits. He looks up. Already he misses her. Music. ON BENJAMIN’S MUDDY NEW BOOTS Hitting the ground. INT. BENJAMIN’S OFFICE -- DAY A mountain of paperwork is stacked in the middle of the d It's so tall, it obscures most of Benjamin's body. Skinny RHONDA THE SECRETARY, 20's, drops off another billing she

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan draws. A clock by the backyard says 4:10 PM. Here comes Lily with a basket of sandwiches. “She drops one of for him, and exits. He opens it up and sees a note. It reads: “Hi Dylan” along with a sunny drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mountain of paperwork is now even bigger. We can only see the top of Benjamin’s head. Rhonda drops two more billing sheets onto the top of the stack. EXT. BACKYARD -— DAY Dylan opens up the sandwich. There is a note for him. It reads: Hil Have fun in the Underworld! L

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN'S BOOTS
dialogues.text: Broken in. Music ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin cooks dinner for his family. He serves corn on t cob and potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I forgot to buy butter.  35.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: That's okay, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: How important is butter to this meal? I'll take a vote. Just keep in mind, it’s ni miles a to the grocery store. Is butter worth your dad driving 18 miles? Okay let’s vote. They look at him. They miss butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin exits car, having driven 18 miles, returning wit grocery bag. He sees Kelly, still at work.

dialogues.speaker: RELLY
dialogues.text: Long day for you, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Tong day for you. You should go. We'll take over -- we're good. She looks at Benjamin, a dish-towel over his shoulder. Dy mopes out from the porch. Benjamin holds up the grocery b like a trophy. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) 18 miles for butter! Dylan bows, thank you. BENJAMIN (CONT‘D) Where’s your sister? Is she with the peacocks? Dylan points. Of course she is. Rosie ambles up the driveway, followed by her peacocks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSTE
dialogues.text: Dad, Kelly, guess what? I gave everyone a name. (pointing to each peacock) This is Lucy, and Wes, and Peaches and Coco, and Doctor Lou, and Jackpot.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s great! “Jackpot.”

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Honey, that’s great. What a great name. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I'm talking with Kelly here, she needs to go home and get some time to herself. dust tell us whatever we can do to finish up.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Are you sure? He looks at her. Yes, sure. Kelly continues, in one breat KELLY (CONT’D) Okay -— so you need to put some water in the tiger habitat -- Spar has some new medication, it’s in his food, make sure he finished it. Then turn off the lights in the reptile enclosure. We got a big shipment of African garter snakes, you can leave those in the travel crate, they’ll go into the exhibit tomorrow. She’s so relieved to have remembered everything.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, and the monkeys need fruit.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Kelly. Have fun, go out. Go into the city...

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Think I'll just go to my pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You too Benjamin. She stops. KELLY {CONT’D) I forgot that thing you wanted me to remember for you.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Go home! He is touched by her determination, as she finally exits. stands tall on the porch.  37. EXT. ZOO —- NIGHT The kids follow Benjamin across the zoo — Rosie happily, Dylan begrudgingly. Doing chores.

dialogues.speaker: DYLAN
dialogues.text: «+. IT have a sick amount of homework tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Unhuh. Let’s go. Rosie and I are going to give the tigers some water... Dylan you head over to the snake enclosure and make sure the lights are off in the side room. They need darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where the tigers sleep at night. Rosie watches Benjamin put water in the tiger enclosure. Benjamin looks Spar. He talks to the animal soothingly, with growing ski

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: You take your meds, Old Man? (he checks) Good. Gotta keep taking those pills, or Kelly’1ll drive ya nuts. He leans forward, tells him a secret.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think she likes you guys more than she likes people. Whaddya think? Spar lazily blinks his eyes at her. Rosie laughs softly, appreciating them both.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: He looks tired, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: He’s going to be okay. Spar looks at Benjamin.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aren’t you, Buddy? Spar blinks. He rolls over slightly, stretching happily. BENJAMIN (CONT’D) See? He likes us.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Dylan really loves you, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BENJAMIN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: He's just mad that his friends don’t visit him here. He thought they'd all visit and nobody came. Benjamin nods to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dylan walks in, looks around. The room is filled with lif The reptiles perch on fake trees and watch him, curious. about to switch off the lights in the back room when he s the plastic travel crate. From the grated side he can see dozens of snakes, waiting to be put into the habitat. It’ Marked: AFRICAN GARTER SNAKES, NON-VENOMOUS. Dylan slowly opens the box and looks inside.
